text: <@U03V8V08M>: we were talking about Shazam on thursday, then this popped up on HN or proggit or something <http://coding-geek.com/how-shazam-works/>

attachments.title: How does Shazam work - Coding Geek
attachments.text: Have you ever wondered how shazam works ? In this in-depth post I explain the mechanisms behind shazam.
attachments.fallback: Coding Geek: How does Shazam work - Coding Geek

text: <@U06BGNMBL>: I vaguely remember a conversation around the idea of going _from_ the signature back to the audio

I think this sort of thing's a one way street really, but we were also thinking about how you could create an audio recording that produced the same fourier transform output as a popular song but sounded like total nonsense
and false positives in contentid, etc
anyway, that's a good little intro for idiots like me who couldn't quicksort an empty list :simple_smile:
I use bogo sort, it’s never let me down

I had to look that up, which was rewarding. "An in-joke among some computer scientists is that quantum computing could be used to effectively implement a bogosort with a time complexity of O(n).[8] First, use quantum randomness to permute the list. The quantum randomization creates n! branches of the wavefunction ("universes" in many-worlds interpretation), and one of these will be such that this single shuffle had produced the list in sorted order. The list is then inspected, and if it is not sorted, the universe is destroyed."
So basically the whole plot of Donnie Darko happens because some smartarse was trying to sort a deck of cards at a DARPA research facility
